The Moon Phase Anomaly in the Antikythera Mechanism
Figure 1: Back side of Fragment C, in which the moon cap is visible using PTM technology. Copyright of the Antikythera Mechanism Research Project.
The Moon Phase Anomaly in the Antikythera Mechanism
Figure 2: Front and back of the moon phase device built by Michael Wright. Figure taken from Wright 2006: 328.
The Moon Phase Anomaly in the Antikythera Mechanism

Figure 3: Detail of fragment C showing the moon cap. In the upper left corner a detail of the contrate gear showing the direction of the teeth. Copyright of the Antikythera Mechanism Research Project.
The Moon Phase Anomaly in the Antikythera Mechanism
Figure 4: Freeth's proposal for connecting the contrate gear to the sun axis.
The Moon Phase Anomaly in the Antikythera Mechanism

Figure 5: Master Diagram: In red, the moon cap plate with its features (the Tau, the rectangular hole, the big window and the footprint of the semicircular rim); in blue, the arbor and all that is or was attached to it (the contrate gear, the square collar, the arbor itself and the remains of the moon ball); in green, the cheeks; and in violet, the arbor keeper pipe. The sizes are expressed in mm.
The Moon Phase Anomaly in the Antikythera Mechanism

Animation 3: The step by step disassembly of the Moon phase mechanism.
The Moon Phase Anomaly in the Antikythera Mechanism
Figure 18: Oldest extant picture of Fragment C (Svoronos 1903). The contrate's orientation is the same as today.
The Moon Phase Anomaly in the Antikythera Mechanism
Figure 19: Schematic reconstruction of the moon phase device as extant in fragment C. Note the three points labeled a, b and c. A break in the arbor is clearly visible between b and c.
The Moon Phase Anomaly in the Antikythera Mechanism
Figure 20: Option 1: the contrate is facing the other direction, keeping all the other elements in their places. The gear does not fit in the gear-window.
The Moon Phase Anomaly in the Antikythera Mechanism
Figure 21: Option 2: the contrate is facing the other direction and the collar is located between border a and the gear.
The Moon Phase Anomaly in the Antikythera Mechanism
Figure 22: the broken part of the arbor, together with the collar and the contrate gear, has been reversed.
The Moon Phase Anomaly in the Antikythera Mechanism
Figure 23: the matching between border b and c. Copyright of the Antikythera Mechanism Research Project.
The Moon Phase Anomaly in the Antikythera Mechanism
Figure 24: the arbor shouldn’t protrude beyond the collar.
The Moon Phase Anomaly in the Antikythera Mechanism
Figure 25: remains of the cylindrical arbor at the collar, before the break. Copyright of the Antikythera Mechanism Research Project.
The Moon Phase Anomaly in the Antikythera Mechanism

Figure 26: possible break of the pipe that remains attached to the collar. The break is below and to the right of the arbor, so it seems to be a piece of the pipe and not of the arbor. Copyright of the Antikythera Mechanism Research Project.
The Moon Phase Anomaly in the Antikythera Mechanism

Figure 27: possible break of the pipe that remains attached to the collar. The break is below and to the left of the arbor, so it seems to be a piece of the pipe and not of the arbor. Copyright of the Antikythera Mechanism Research Project.
The Moon Phase Anomaly in the Antikythera Mechanism

Figure 28: Reconstruction of the rim attached to the moon cap. The extremities intersect the point at which the arbor of the two extra gears must be located and the opening is just the required to accommodate the gears. If a support of the arbor was necessary at the top of the gears for mechanical reasons, it could be easily added.
The Moon Phase Anomaly in the Antikythera Mechanism

Figure 29: Another way to fix the gears. The bridge holding the arbor of the two extra gears could be attached to the cheeks. If a support of the arbor was necessary at the top of the gears for mechanical reasons, it could be easily added.
The Moon Phase Anomaly in the Antikythera Mechanism
